msItem.rubric: liber YSIDORI [expanded by Gascoigne to ‘incipit liber ysidori episcopi de libris noui ac ueteris testamenti’]
msItem.incipit: De librorum novi ac ueteris testamenti plenitudine quam in canone catholica recipit ȩcclesia
msItem.explicit: Apocalypsim Iohannes euangelista scripsit eodem tempore quo ob euangelii predicationem insula pathmos traditur relegatus Hij sunt scriptores sacrorum librorum diuina inspiratione loquentes pro sanctorum etiam librorum numerum postulata sequentia prenotabo
msItem.finalRubric: [Gascoigne adds:] finis sancti ISOIDORI [as the opening rubric]
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: In libros ueteris et noui testamenti prooemia
msItem.note: CPL 1192, ed. PL 83:155–78, with both Acts and Apoc. truncated to a single sentence each and a concluding paragraph (beginning ‘Hij scriptores’) not in the edition. Divided into Old and New Testament sections by a large capital on fol. 53v, with some material on Old Testament apocrypha inserted into the New Testament account.

msItem.rubric: [the rubric Gascoigne’s] Incipit liber eiusdem de ortu uita et obitu sanctorum patrum qui in sacra scriptura nominantur

msItem.explicit: ad instruendas cretȩ ecclesias misit prefatus apostolus ibique et in pace sepultus est [Gascoigne in the margin:] hic est finis sancti ISIDORI episcopi de patribus veteris ac noui testamenti
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: De ortu et obitu patrum

msItem.incipit: Orosio suo YSIDORUS salutem Quedam notissima nomina legis et euangeliorum que sub allegoria imaginarie obteguntur
msItem.explicit: in qua omnes sancti per cristum eterne beatitudinis refectione saturabuntur
msItem.finalRubric: Explicit liber YSIDORI SPALENSIS episcopi de significationibus quorundam uirorum sanctorum
msItem.author: Isidore of Seville
msItem.title: ‘Allegoriae quaedam Sacrae Scripturae’
msItem.note: (CPL 1190), ed. PL 83:97–130. Gascoigne explains (fol. 76, lower margin): ‘Incipit supra ibi opus aliud sancti ISIDORI de patribus noui et ueteris testamenti quis cuius tipum gesserit et dicitur allegoria veteris et noui testamenti per ISIDORUM.

msItem.rubric: In nomine domini incipiunt capitula sequentis operis | [fol. 102] Incipit liber magni AURELII CASSIODORI senatoris de institutionibus diuinarum litterarum
msItem.incipit: Cvm studia secularium litterarum magno desiderio feruere cognoscerem ita ut multa pars
msItem.explicit: utile esse promittitur si pro nobis inuicem pio domino supplicemus [Gascoigne adds:] explicit CASSIODORUS de institucione diuinarum scripturarum
msItem.author: Cassiodorus
msItem.title: Institutiones
msItem.note: CPL 906, book 1 only; ed. R. A. B. Mynors (Oxford, 1937), 3–85. Preceded (fols. 101v–2) by a table of chapters.

msItem.incipit: Sanctus paulus apostolus Virgo fuit in tota vita sua ad mortem suam
msItem.explicit: remotis partibus occidentis scilicet hispania et in finibus aquilonis et austri
msItem.note: Added by Gascoigne in the lower margin following item 7.

msItem.incipit: Piissimo patri et domino Vrbano dei gracia sancte et uniuersalis ecclesie pastori dignissimo Ianuenses consules de quem debitam in omnibus cum subiectione reuerentiam Ex celis fame uolatij sanctissime pater et lugubri ciuis nostri de transmarinis partibus redeuntis
msItem.explicit: ad sanctitatis uestre noticiam peruenisse non dubitamus mandatis uestris tamquam patris et domini nulla ratione deerimus
msItem.note: A letter from Genoese ambassadors to pope Urban III, announcing the fall of Jerusalem to Saladin (1187), ed. Karl Hampe, Neues Archiv 22 (1896), 227–80.

msItem.incipit: Frater TERRICUS paupermme pauperimme domus templi dictus magnus preceptor omnisque fratrum pauperimus et fere omnino adnichilatus conuentus
msItem.explicit: residuas ciuitates nostro fulti amminiculo saluare possimus Valete
msItem.note: A letter from TERRICUS, preceptor of the Templars, on the same subject, ed. PL 201:1408–10. These two texts written in a single late s. xii hand.

msItem.incipit: Ludovicus dei gratia Romanorum Imperator Saladino presidi Saracenorum quondam uiro illustri Ierusalem fugere exemplo faraonis Deuotionis tue litteras multis retro
msItem.explicit: dies illa plena reuerentie et iocunditatis triumpho cristi prefixa te docebit
msItem.note: In fact a letter of emperor FREDERICK I challenging Saladin, ed. F. Liebermann and R. Paul, ‘ex Itinerario peregrinorum auctore Ricardo Londoniensi’, MGH Scriptores, 27:197. (Richard does not appear in Sharpe.) Written in a transitional protogothic bookhand/gothic textura, s. xiii in. Fol. 146v is blank.

msItem.incipit: Ex insperato et in transitu mihi dei gratia propitiante nuper innotuit quod ad uos erat
msItem.explicit: non potest esse ambiguum qui uarias scripturas sollerti indagatione [the first letters reinked] diligentius perscrutatur
msItem.author: JOHN OF SALISBURY
msItem.note: (Sharpe, no. 872 [309–10]), epistola 305, describing the death of Becket; ed. W. J. Millor and C. N. L. Brooke, John of Salisbury: The Letters, 2 vols. (Oxford, 1979), 2:724–39. In double columns, written in transitional protogothic bookhand/gothic textura, s. xii/xiii. Most of fol. 148ra and all of the second column blank.

msItem.incipit: Ideo in ecclesia dei antiquam patrum consuetudinem concilia congregantur ut hii qui constituti sunt
msItem.explicit: urgentissima interueniente necessitate pro bono pacis talis coniunctio toleretur
msItem.title: The preamble and canons of the council of Westminster (May 1175)
msItem.note: ed. D. Whitelock, M. Brett, and C. N. L. Brooke, Councils and Synods, I, ii (Oxford, 1981), 983–91; our MS mentioned at 972.

supportDesc.collation: 1–178 1810 194(–4), the last of these quires supplied later to hold the added texts. No catchwords. A few early quires signed with a roman numeral on the last verso; in this system, quires 2–7 = II–vii.

layoutDesc.layout: In long lines, 26 lines to the page. No prickings; bounded and ruled in black ink.

handDesc.handNote: Written in caroline; a good many titles either explicated or provided by an anglicana/secretary hand, s. xv med., that of Thomas Gascoigne (for him, see BRUO 745–8). Punctuation by medial point and punctus elevatus.

decoDesc.decoNote: Headings in red, especially frequent in the margin in text 2; the first is in rustic capitals, as are the openings of some texts.
At the heads of the texts, 6- and 7-line red and green arabesque initials, with plant designs including blue and gold.
At divisions, alternate 2-line red and green arabesque initials.

binding.p: Dark brown leather over millboards, with a stamped fillet on both boards, s. xvii. Sewn on four thongs. Gold ‘115’ at the head of the spine; in black ink on the leading edges, also spattered with a bit of red. Pastedowns modern paper, a College bookplate on the front pastedown. At the front, two modern paper fly- leaves; at the rear; two more (iii–iv).

history.provenance: In Oxford s. xv med. and annotated by Thomas Gascoigne, chancellor of the university; his customary marks ‘ihesus maria’ frequently at the upper edges, e.g. fols. 1–4v, 5v (partly Greek), 7v, etc. For him and his bequests of books, see BRUO 745–8 (our MS unnoted in a long list of books he owned and annotated) and Winifred A. Pronger, ‘Thomas Gascoigne’, English Historical Review 53 (1938), 606–26, our MS mentioned at 623 n. 6.
‘deo gracias quia legi totum librum istum anno gracie 1487. infra spacium x. dierum ab eius inceptione finem faciendo 19. die septembris circa mediam noctem’ (fol. 145, lower margin).
